questions.text: Which among the following phases indicates complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arteriovenous phase Complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries is seen in the arterio-venous phase. Arterio-venous phase- complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries followed by laminar filling of veins In FFA, sodium fluorescein dye is injected into the antecubital vein. A fundus camera is then used to take photographs: 1st picture-after 5 seconds, then every second for 20 seconds, every 3-5 seconds for the next 1 minute • Last picture- after 10 minutes.

Highyeild:

The phases of the Fundus Fluorescein Angiography in a normal Angiogram are in the following order - Choroidal Phase /Pre-Arterial Phase Arterial Phase Arteriovenous Phase Early Venous Phase Mid-Venous Phase Late Venous Phase

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Pre-arterial phase - choroidal circulation is filling Option: B . Arterial phase -start filling of retinal arteriole till it's filled Option: D . Venous filling- arterioles are emptying, and veins are filling

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a business executive came with a sudden painless diminution of vision into the emergency department. After certain basic investigations, he was advised to undergo a fundus fluorescein Angiography and the following finding was noted. Which of the following statements regarding the fluorescence of the condition is TRUE?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperfluorescence due to Pooling The given Clinical vignette with a sudden painless blurring of the with an FFA showing a Smokestack appearance suggests a diagnosis of Central Serous Retinopathy . CSR is an example of a Pooling Type of Fluorescence (Option D) The usual management of Central Serous Retinopathy is to WAIT and WATCH because the condition resolves itself in 1 to 3 months . Fundus Fluorescein Angiography, where Intravenous Fluorescein dye is injected to check for fluid leakage . This would reveal fluid leakage through a defect seen in the layer of Bruch's membrane. Smokestack pattern /Mushroom Appearance is a characteristic feature of Central Serous Retinopathy.

Highyeild:

Pooling occurs due to the breakdown of tight junctions of the retinal pigment epithelium. In the case of Central Serous Retinopathy, it appears in the subretinal space.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A. Diabetic retinopathy, Retinal Venous Occlusion and Papilloedema are domes the examples of hyper fluorescence due to Leakage Option:B. Exposed Sclera and fibrous tissue are some examples of Hyperfluorescence due to Staining Option:C. Pseudofluorescence means false fluorescence . It is due to the reflected light, which is not fluorescent, seen before the fluorescein dye injection.

Extraedge:

An early hyper fluorescence characterizes it through a small tear. It then slowly increases in the covered area and brightness while the involved area is still well-defined.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who has been a known Diabetic for more than 15 years was referred to the ophthalmology OPD as he had symptoms suggestive of retinopathy. After certain basic investigations, he was asked to undergo Fundus Fluorescein Angiography. Which of the following are NOT USES of FFA in a case of Diabetic Retinopathy?

options.label: A
options.text: Useful for both confirmation and treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy

options.label: B
options.text: Helps to differentiate IRMA from new vessel formation

options.label: C
options.text: Helps to outline the leakage area but not the FAZ

options.label: D
options.text: Helps to guide in laser therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Helps to outline the leakage area but not the FAZ
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Helps to outline the leakage area but not the FAZ FFA helps to outline both the leakage and the Foveal Avascular Zone , also Diabetic retinopathy is the leading cause of blindness in patients between 25 and 74 yrs of age. Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation , which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage to the retinal microvasculature . The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc, characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

Highyeild:

Classification- Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents without the proliferation of new vessels. Mild- Any or all microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhage, exudates, cotton wool spots No IRMA or significant beading Moderate- Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA Significant venous bleeding in 1 quadrant Cotton wool spots Severe 4-2-1 rule, one of Severe hemorrhage in all four quadrants Essential venous beading in more than two quadrants Moderate IRMA in more than one quadrant Very severe Two or more of the 4-2-1 rule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Fundus Fluorescein Angiography is helpful both for diagnosis and also in the treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy Advantages in Diagnosis: It helps to find the non-perfused areas helps to find neovascularization of the disc and elsewhere (NVD & NVE) Option: B. To delineate IRMA from the new vessels formed To rule out ischaemia in the macula

Extraedge:

Treatment: Helps To outline leakage area in the field Option: C . Helps to find the boundaries of FAZ Option: D . Helps to guide laser therapy for CSME

questions.text: Below are a few options for various varieties of Fluorescence in an FFA. Which of the following options is NOT a cause for Hypofluorescence?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystoid Macular Edema Cystoid Macular Edema is an Example of hyper fluorescence (Leakage Type) and not a cause of hypo fluorescence . CME: There is a collection of fluid in the outer plexiform ( Henle’s layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina centered around the foveola Ophthalmoscopy shows a “ honeycomb appearance of the macula.” It is a late postoperative complication of cataract surgery. There is a role of prostaglandin in the pathogenesis of CME. Anterior vitrectomy is recommended when CME with vitreous incarceration occurs. After cataract surgery, Anti- prostaglandin [ indomethacin, flurbiprofen, ketorolac ] is recommended in the prophylaxis of CME.
